message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diuretic that predominantly affects the thick ascending loop of Henle is loop diuretics like furosemide. Thiazides work on the distal tubule, while potassium-sparing diuretics work on the collecting ducts. Proximal tubule diuretics have not been developed. The decrease in serum calcium and magnesium levels is a known side effect of loop diuretics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diuretic mentioned in the question is most likely a loop diuretic, which acts predominantly on the thick ascending loop of Henle to decrease reabsorption of sodium and water, leading to increased urinary excretion of these ions. Loop diuretics can also cause loss of other electrolytes, including calcium and magnesium, as they are also reabsorbed predominantly in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diuretic that acts predominantly on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is a loop diuretic, such as furosemide or bumetanide. These diuretics can cause hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia due to their ability to inhibit reabsorption of these electrolytes in the thick ascending limb. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Thick ascending loop of Henle.
